message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and examination suggest normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), and the improvement of gait with lumbar puncture adds to the evidence. Ventriculoperitoneal shunt is the preferred treatment for NPH. The other options are not relevant to the management of this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The head CT suggests hydrocephalus, which can cause gait and balance problems, as well as memory and cognitive issues. The transient improvement after lumbar puncture also supports the diagnosis of hydrocephalus. The next step in management is to place a ventriculoperitoneal shunt to relieve the hydrocephalus. Options A, B, and C are not appropriate for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the head CT suggest hydrocephalus. The temporary improvement after the lumbar puncture confirms the diagnosis. Ventriculoperitoneal shunt is the treatment of choice for hydrocephalus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The CT scan shows ventricular enlargement, suggesting normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). The improvement in gait after lumbar puncture confirms the diagnosis. Ventriculoperitoneal shunt is the most effective treatment for NPH, with improvements in gait and urinary incontinence.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including difficulty walking and maintaining balance, suggest that she has normal pressure hydrocephalus. The improvement in symptoms following a lumbar puncture confirms the diagnosis. The next step in management is a ventriculoperitoneal shunt, which can help to relieve the hydrocephalus and improve the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and CT scan suggest normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), and the lumbar puncture confirms the diagnosis. The treatment for NPH is ventriculoperitoneal shunt. Other options are not indicated for NPH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The head CT shows ventriculomegaly, which suggests normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). The temporary improvement after lumbar puncture supports the diagnosis of NPH. The next step in management of NPH is ventriculoperitoneal shunt.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including difficulty walking and maintaining balance, suggest hydrocephalus, which is supported by the CT scan. The improvement in gait after lumbar puncture further suggests hydrocephalus. Ventriculoperitoneal shunt is the next step in managing hydrocephalus. Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used for treating glaucoma, epileptic seizure, and altitude sickness. Endoscopic third ventriculostomy is a surgery for treating hydrocephalus, but it’s not the next step for this patient. Epidural blood patch is a treatment for postdural puncture headache.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The CT scan findings suggest normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) and the improvement in gait after lumbar puncture confirms it. Ventriculoperitoneal shunt is the next step in management for NPH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The head CT scan shows ventriculomegaly, which suggests normal pressure hydrocephalus. The fact that the patient’s gait was temporarily improved with a lumbar puncture supports this diagnosis. The next step in management is a ventriculoperitoneal shunt, which can help alleviate symptoms in patients with normal pressure hydrocephalus.
